attributes.title: A meta-analytic investigation of the relationship between self-estimated and psychometrically assessed intelligence

q1.value: A meta-analytic investigation of the relationship between self-estimated and psychometrically assessed intelligence

q3.value: The ability to make a valid assessment of our abilities has great importance for example for career decisions or everyday activities such as driving a car (Freund & Kasten, 2011). Previous evidence suggests that the correlation between self-evaluation and objective performance of different ability types varies strongly (Zell & Krizan, 2014). A previous meta-analysis focussed on the validity of self-estimated cognitive abilities (Freund & Kasten, 2011). Since the validity of self-estimated intelligence (=SAI) remains a topic of high importance and newer statistical methods have been established (e.g. for testing of publication bias) the main purpose of the proposed study will be to replicate the meta-analysis by Freund and Kasten (2011), while using newer statistical methods. In addition to the studies included by Freund and Kasten, new studies from 2011 to 2020 will be analysed.

q4.value:
General effect: 
Freund and Kasten (2011) found a positive overall relationship between self-estimated and psychometrically measured cognitive ability (r= .34). Therefore, we expect to find a significant, positive relationship between the two variables as well (H1). 

Moderator variables:
Based on previous studies (e.g. Freund & Kasten, 2011; Zell & Krizan, 2014) we do not expect the average, true effect size to be the same for all the studies. Instead, we assume there to be a significant amount of in-between study variance. We aim to explain part of this variation by a total of 9 moderator variables, some of which were already included in the original meta-analysis.

The methodology of self-evaluation (H2): The correlation between SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence will be higher when SAI is assessed using relative scales compared to absolute scales. The correlation will be even higher if an explicit reference group is named. The correlation between self-estimated and psychometrically assessed intelligence will not increase significantly when using a mixed scale compared to an absolute one. 

Ability type (H3): The correlation between self-assessed and psychometrically assessed numerical, verbal and spatial abilities will be higher, than for self-assessed and psychometrically assessed general cognitive ability. Additionally, the correlation will be higher for well-known “standard skills” (numerical, verbal and spatial abilities) compared to rarely assessed abilities. 

Order of assessment (H4): There will be no significant differences in the correlation between SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence depending on the order of assessment. 

Sex of participants (H5): There will be no significant sex differences in the correlation between SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence.

Sample composition (H6): For non-academic participants, the correlation between self-assessed and psychometrically assessed intelligence will be higher than for academic participants. 

Year of publication (H7): The year of publication will not influence the correlation between SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence. 

Selection Process (H8): If the intelligence was assessed as part of a selection process, the correlation between SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence will be lower compared to "normal" test conditions. 

Self-efficacy (H9): The higher a person's self-efficacy value, the higher the correlation between SAI and psychometric intelligence will be. 

Neuroticism (H10): The higher a person's neuroticism value, the lower the correlation between SAI and psychometric intelligence will be.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A meta-analytic investigation of the correlation between self-assessed and psychometrically assessed intelligence.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Since the planned study is a meta-analysis, most of the data has already been published or does at least exist without being published. For all those studies included by Freund and Kasten (2011), effect sizes, sample sizes and study characteristics are known. 
At this point, we have not searched for any studies systematically and I have neither extracted any information nor calculated meta-analytical statistics.

question.value:
To find all studies that should potentially be included in the meta-analysis,  online databases PsychINFO, PSYNDEX, Scopus, ISI Web of Science, Google Scholar and OATD will be searched, using the following search string: 

(„cognitive ability“ OR „intelligenc*“) AND (estimate* OR perceive* OR self-apprais* OR self-assess* OR self-estimate* OR self-evaluat* OR self-perceive* OR self-rate*).

The databases will be searched systematically with forward searches (articles, that cite Freund and Kasten (2011)) as well as backward searches based on the identified papers and the already included studies. We will also consider unpublished data, grey literature and translate studies using deepl.com if they were not published in English. 
Like Freund and Kasten (2011), we will include all studies that meet the following inclusion criteria:

 1) To be included a study has to compare a self-estimate of cognitive ability (intelligence) to a psychometrically assessed ability test measure. 

2) This psychometric measure has to be collected using a standardized cognitive ability test. Standardized means that, the test is administered in a standardized way, is objectively scored (either manually or electronically by the test administrator or a third person) and offers norms that allow comparisons to the norm sample. Such norms can either be included in the test manual or be derived from the data collected from the study sample (e.g. when the test battery was developed exclusively for this study). To ensure high levels of objectivity and comparability with regard to the criteria observed, other criterion measures, such as grades or experts'/others’ including teachers, parents, and peers) estimates of cognitive ability, will not be included. 

3) A direct measure of self-assessed cognitive ability has to be used. Studies with indirect measures of self-estimations (e.g. conclusions that were drawn from subjects’ estimates of constructs that are related to cognitive ability, e.g., interest) will not be included.

4) Except for those studies, that were included by Freund and Kasten (2011), all included studies must have been conducted between 2011 and 2020. 

5) Only studies, that include healthy adult participants will be considered.

The screening of title, abstract and full texts as well as data extraction will be performed by the author. Results and all relevant details of the screening and literature search will be displayed in a PRISMA Flowchart. 

From all relevant studies, the following information will be extracted: 
-study authors
-correlation coefficient between SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence
-z-transformed correlation coefficient
-standard error of effect size (r)
-sample size
-reliability of self-assessment
-test reliability
-methodology of self-assessment
-ability type
-order of assessment
-sex of participants
-sample composition
-year of publication
-selection process
-mean self-efficacy
-number of answer options (self-efficacy)
-achievable points of self-efficacy scale
-mean neuroticism
-achievable points of neuroticism scale
-number of answer options (neuroticism)
-total number of self-efficacy items
-total number of neuroticism items
-test

Additionally, each included study will be given a unique study ID to allow easy tracking. The coding manual with full description will be included in the supplemental material and attached to the final paper.

q13.value: The final number of included studies will depend on the literature search and extraction process and can not be set at this point.

question.value: Not applicable.

Variables from the published studies and unpublished data sets will be collected, as outlined under "Data collection procedures". For a further description of these variables see coding manual (supplemental material).

The summary effect will be calculated using the R packages ‘metafor’ (Viechtbauer, 2010). As studies are expected to use several different measures to assess the self-assessed and psychometrically assessed intelligence a correction for unreliability seems reasonable (Card, 2012). Therefore, a measurement correction of the effect sizes (i.e. Pearsons r) and standard errors will be performed: First, the square root of the reliability of self-estimated intelligence multiplied by the reliability of the psychometric test will be taken. Second, the effect size (i.e. correlation) and standard error, will be divided by the unreliability to get the adjusted effect size and standard error  (Hunter & Schmidt, 2004). Subsequently, the observed and corrected mean will be compared. In case, that a study contains not enough information to calculate the adjusted values of both SAI and psychometrically assessed intelligence it will be excluded for summery effect calculations. Any exclusions will be made transparent and documented.

Due to high observed study heterogeneity in the preceding meta-analysis by Freund and Kasten (2011), a random-effects meta-analysis with a restricted (residual) maximum-likelihood estimator (REML) will be conducted. 

In line with the previous meta-analysis (Freund & Kasten, 2011), it can be expected that single studies will report multiple effect sizes. In order to cope with dependencies between effect sizes, hierarchical linear modelling (HLM) approach to meta-analysis (Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), also known as 'multilevel meta-analysis', will be used. At Level 1 (base level) the model is a random-effects model. Similar to Freund and Kasten (2011) both a within- and a between-study model will be formulated. At Level 2, moderators at relationship level (all moderators except for 'publication year') will be included (within-study model). Level 3 will include all moderators at study level (between-study model). In order to check the specific effect of a moderator on the overall effect, subgroup analysis will be conducted. 

Since multiple studies found, that there might be a relationship between self-efficacy and neuroticism (e.g. Ackerman & Wolman, 2007; Judge & Ilies, 2002) multicollinearity between these two moderators has to be expected. Therefore, the analysis is performed twice separately for neuroticism and self-efficacy. Since, as mentioned above, the corrected overall mean (Hunter & Schmidt, 2004) will be compared to the observed overall mean, this ultimately leads to a total of four analyses. 

Study heterogeneity will be described by reporting the Q statistic, tau, tau², and I². In order to detect which studies (or effect sizes, since multiple effect sizes per study are expected) influence the overall estimate the most leave-one-out sensitivity analyses will be performed by excluding one study/effect size at a time. Furthermore, a baujat plot (Baujat et al., 2002) will be used to investigate the contribution of each study/effect size to the overall heterogeneity. 

Potential publication bias will be investigated by using the following methods: p-curve (Simonsohn et al., 2014), p-uniform (van Assen et al., 2015), p-uniform* (van Aert & van Assen, 2018), PET-PEESE (Stanley & Doucouliagos, 2014), Begg and Mazumdar's rank-order correlation (1994), Sterne and Egger's regression approach (2005), moderator analysis of published vs. unpublished literature (Card, 2012), Duval & Tweedie’s trim-and-fill procedure (2002) and test for excess significance following the approach of Ioannidis and Trikalinos (2007). Furthermore, studies will be displayed in enhanced funnel plots (Peters et al., 2008) to investigate the funnel plot asymmetry.

q20.value: Transformations include Fisher's r-to-z transformation as well as (depending on the reported effect size) t to r (Borenstein et al., 2009), Beta (regression) to r (Peterson and Brown, 2005) and so on. Since different studies will have used different scaled and a different number of items to measure neuroticism and self-efficacy their means have to be made comparable. Therefore, a relative mean for neuroticism and self-efficacy will be computed, by multiplying the number of answer options (e.g. 5-point scale) by the number of questions (e.g. 12 questions). Subsequently, the average raw score (e.g. 20) will be divided by that value. (20/(12*5)=0.333).

q21.value: The overall estimate is assumed to be significant if confidence intervals do not include zero. If zero is included there is no effect. For the publication bias analysis, an alpha of 0.10 will be chosen.

q22.value: If estimating an effect size (correlation) is not possible due to missing data, the study will be excluded from any following analysis. Any exclusions will be made transparent and documented.

q23.value: In the case of missing data, authors will be contacted. If there is no way to access the missing data, studies may have to be excluded from analysis (see “Data exclusion”)

Since multiple studies found, that there might be a relationship between self-efficacy and neuroticism (e.g. Ackerman & Wolman, 2007; Judge & Ilies, 2002) multicollinearity between these two moderators has to be expected. Therefore, the analysis is performed twice separately for neuroticism and self-efficacy. Since, as mentioned above, the corrected overall mean (Hunter & Schmidt, 2004) will be compared to the observed overall mean, this ultimately leads to a total of four analyses. 

Study heterogeneity will be described by reporting the Q statistic, tau, tau², and I². In order to detect which studies (or effect sizes, since multiple effect sizes per study are expected) influence the overall estimate the most leave-one-out sensitivity analyses will be performed by excluding one study/effect size at a time. Furthermore, a baujat plot (Baujat et al., 2002) will be used to investigate the contribution of each study/effect size to the overall heterogeneity. 

Potential publication bias will be investigated by using the following methods: p-curve (Simonsohn et al., 2014), p-uniform (van Assen et al., 2015), p-uniform* (van Aert & van Assen, 2018), PET-PEESE (Stanley & Doucouliagos, 2014), Begg and Mazumdar's rank-order correlation (1994), Sterne and Egger's regression approach (2005), moderator analysis of published vs. unpublished literature (Card, 2012), Duval & Tweedie’s trim-and-fill procedure (2002) and test for excess significance following the approach of Ioannidis and Trikalinos (2007). Furthermore, studies will be displayed in enhanced funnel plots (Peters et al., 2008) to investigate the funnel plot asymmetry.

attributes.title: Figur Hukum Baitul Maal wat Tamwil (BMT) Sebagai Lembaga Ekonomi Kerakyatan

q1.value: Figur Hukum Baitul Maal wat Tamwil Sebagai Lembaga Ekonomi Kerakyatan

q3.value: Buku ini mengkaji aspek hukum Baitul Maal wat Tamwil (BMT) yang diawali dengan uraian mengenai BMT sebagai Lembaga Keuangan Mikro Syariah. BMT juga merupakan salah satu model sistem ekonomi kerakyatan yang perkembangannya dapat menopang percepatan pertumbuhan ekonomi nasional, namun secara yuridis, BMT didirikan dan dikembangkan dengan suatu proses legalitas hukum yang bertahap. Status BMT ditentukan oleh jumlah aset yang dimiliki, maka BMT memiliki status hukum yang berbeda pula sesuai dengan tahapan jumlah aset tersebut, serta tunduk pada hukum yang beragam dan parsial sesuai dengan tahap status hukum. Untuk itu, dalam buku ini, Penulis akan menguraikan konsep hukum pengaturan lembaga BMT di masa yang akan datang.

attributes.title: Implementasi E Government Pemerintahan Desa Dalam Administrasi Pelayanan Publik (Studi Kasus Web Site Desa Kanie Kecamatan Maritengngae Kabupaten Sidenreng Rappang)
attributes.description: Sistem informasi berkembang semakin pesat ditandai adanya pemanfaatan internet. Internet sebagai media penyampai informasi keberadaanya kini sudah menjadi kebutuhan. Manfaat internet cukup besar dirasakan terutama dalam dunia bisnis, hiburan, maupun pemeintahan. Desa Kanie salah satu desa yang terdapat di Kabupaten  Sidenreng Rappang. Desa Kanie mengalami kendala dalam sistem pengenalan struktur organisasi, kegiatan-kegiatan, lokasi, maupun potensi-potensi yang ada di desa tersebut, yang saat ini hanya dikenal oleh masyarakat sekitar saja. Dengan perkembangan teknologi informasi yang semakin pesat maka Desa Kanie juga memerlukan sebuah media promosi yang bersifat online yang dapat juga disebut website promosi desa. Sehingga website promosi ini diharapkan dapat berjalan dengan baik maka akan mempermudah dalam mengenalkan potensi-potensi, maupun administrasi pelayanan publik, yang ada di Desa Kanie. Kegiatan pembuatan website dilakukan di Desa Kanie, Dusun Kanie 1 dan Dusun Labempa dilaksanakan pada Bulan Januari sampai Februari 2020

attributes.title: The Temporal Dynamics of Sitting Behaviour in Cardiovascular Disease Patients and the Impact of Cardiac Rehabilitation

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The Temporal Dynamics of Sitting Behaviour in Cardiovascular Disease Patients and the impact of Cardiac Rehabilitation

other.value:
Existing data:
This study uses existing data collected by the exercise physiology research group at the Radboud University Medical Centre. The original study collected data on sitting behaviour and physical activity in a group of cardiovascular disease (CVD) patients who engaged in cardiac rehabilitation, and a group of healthy, age-matched controls, to (a) compare sitting behaviour characteristics between the two groups and (b) determine the impact of cardiac rehabilitation on sitting behaviour characteristics. 

Secondary analyses per aim:

Aim 2: Investigate changes in sitting patterns of CV patients from before to after cardiac rehabilitation
As a secondary analysis, we additionally compare sitting patterns at post- and follow-up- measurements in CV patients with baseline sitting patterns of healthy controls. 

S1a: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “post”))

S1b: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “follow-up”))

S2a: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “post”))

S2b: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “follow-up”))


 
Aim 3: Explore the temporal dynamics of sitting behaviour in CV patients compared to healthy controls
As a secondary analysis, we additionally compare sitting patterns at post- and follow-up- measurements in CV patients with baseline sitting patterns of healthy controls. 

S3a1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “post”))

S3a2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “post”))

S3b1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “follow-up”))

S3b2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “follow-up”))


S4a1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “post”))

S4a2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “post”))

S4b1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “follow-up”))

S4b2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “follow-up”))

Convergence / singularity issues
When running the shared frailty cox regression model gives convergence or singularity problems, we will walk through the following steps until the problem will be solved:
1.	Rerun the model while disabling the ‘sparse’ method for estimating the correlation matrix. 
2.	Rerun the model with standardized predictors
3.	Simplify the model following recommendations by Barr, Levy, Scheepers, and Tily (2013) 

References
Barr, D. J., Levy, R., Scheepers, C., & Tily, H. J. (2013). Random effects structure for confirmatory hypothesis testing: Keep it maximal. Journal of Memory and Language, 68(3). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jml.2012.11.001
Edwardson, C. L., Winkler, E. A. H., Bodicoat, D. H., Yates, T., Davies, M. J., Dunstan, D. W., & Healy, G. N. (2017). Considerations when using the activPAL monitor in field-based research with adult populations. Journal of Sport and Health Science, 6(2), 162–178. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jshs.2016.02.002
Singer, J. D., & Willet, J. B. (2003). Applied longitudinal data analysis. Oxford University Press.
Therneau, T. M. (2015). A package for survival analysis in S (Version 2.38). http://CRAN.R-project.org/package=survival
Winkler, E., Bodicoat, D., Healy, G., Bakrania, K., Yates, T., Owen, N., Dunstan, D., & Edwardson, C. (2016). Identifying adults’ valid waking wear time by automated estimation in activPAL data collected with a 24 h wear protocol. Physiological Measurement, 37, 1653–1668. https://doi.org/10.1088/0967-3334/37/10/1653

sample.value:
The study will use existing data. Therefore, sample sizes will be predetermined, namely:
CVD patients: n = 131
Healthy controls: n = 116

analyses.value:
We will perform all analyses in R / R studio, using the survival package (Therneau, 2015). We will split the complete data into two dataset: 
•	data_sit.to.stand = will only include event times (rows) for sit-to-stand events
•	data_stand.to.sit = will only include events times (rows) for stand-to-sit events
To test our hypotheses and explore our research questions, we will fit several shared frailty cox models using the coxph function, with the predictor(s) of interest, and a frailty term for participant, as predictors of the hazard to stand up when sitting or the hazard to sit down when standing. We will use the ‘efron’ method for handling ties. Unless otherwise specified, for each model, we will determine statistical significance of the fixed effects and/or interaction effects. When statistically significant, we will interpret the hazard ratio (HR; antilog of the raw coefficient) of the fixed predictors or interactions. In addition, we will visually examine plotted survival function separated for relevant levels of the predictor variables. 

1.	Investigate differences in baseline sitting patterns between CV patients and healthy controls
To test H1 and H2, we will use the pre-cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients, and the data of the healthy controls. We will fit two separate shared frailty cox models with group (1 = CV; 0 = control) as predictor. 

H1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “pre”))

H2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “pre”))

2.	Investigate changes in sitting patterns of CV patients from before to after cardiac rehabilitation
To test H3 and H4, we will use the pre-, post-, and follow-up cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients. We will fit two separate shared frailty cox models with measurement moment (pre, post, follow-up; cr_time) as predictor. We will use treatment contrasts for measurement moment, with the pre-measure as the reference category. 
	
H3: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, group = “cv”))

H4: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, group = “cv”))

3.	Explore the temporal dynamics of sitting behaviour in CV patients compared to healthy controls
For Aim 3, we will use the pre-cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients, and the data of the healthy controls. For each predictor, i.e., time of the day and activity in last 5 hours, we will fit four separate shared frailty cox models: two for each dependent variable. Per predictor and dependent variable, Model 1 includes the respective predictor and group (1 = CV; 0 = control) as predictors. In Model 2, the interaction between the respective predictor and group is added. 

Sit-to-stand:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “pre”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “pre”))

Stand-to-sit:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “pre”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “pre”))

4.	Explore individual characteristics and patient characteristics as predictors of sitting patterns of CV patients
For aim 4, we will use the pre-, post-, and follow-up cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients. For each predictor listed in Questions 3 and 4, we will fit four separate shared frailty cox models: two for each dependent variable. Per predictor and dependent variable, Model 1 includes the respective predictor and measurement moment (pre, post, follow-up; cr-time) as predictors. In Model 2, the interaction between the respective predictor and measurement moment is added. We will use treatment contrasts for measurement moment variable, with the pre-measure as the reference category. We will summarise HRs and confidence intervals for each predictor and each interaction with measurement moment in a dot-whisker diagram. When statistically significant, we will interpret the Predictor x Measurement moment interaction by visual inspection of graphs. 

Sit-to-stand:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, group == “cv”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + predictorxcr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, group == “cv”))

Stand-to-sit:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, group == “cv”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + predictorxcr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, group == “cv”))

outliers.value:
Exclusion criteria
•	Sleep. ActivPAL data during sleep will be identified using self-reported sleep/wake-time diaries from participants. In the original study, an algorithm was used to match self-reported sleep/wake-times to activPAL data. In case the self-reported sleep/wake-times and the activPAL data did not match (i.e., no sedentary episode of long duration starting within the 40 minute time-window around self-reported bedtimes, or ending within the 40 minute timewindow around the self-reported waketimes) these self-reported sleep/wake-times were manually adjusted to plausible bed- or waketimes, based on visual inspection of the activPAL data, as well as consultancy with participants on regular bed and waketimes. These adjusted sleep/wake-time diaries are used for the current study. First, we increase participants self-reported bedtimes and decrease participants self-reported waketimes with 20 minutes. Next, all sedentary and active episodes of a day, that start after the respective adjusted bedtime for that day, and start before the respective adjusted wake time of the next day, are excluded. In addition, all sedentary episodes of a day that end after the adjusted bedtime for that day, and start before the adjusted waketime of the next day, are excluded. 
•	Valid wear-day. We exclude all data on days that are considered invalid wear days (i.e., day on which the participant did not wear the activPAL according to the instructions). A day is considered invalid if at least one of the following criteria is met:
o	One activity takes up more than 95% of totale time awake
o	<500 steps counted
o	<10 hours awake

Assumptions
We will test the assumptions of multilevel time-to-event analysis as follows:
•	Distribution of predictors. We will visually explore histograms to examine the distribution of predictors. In case of serious concerns we will refit the model with a transformation of the predictor variable. We will use a transformation on the predictor that sufficiently creates a normal distribution, starting with square root transformation, followed by log transformation, followed by inverse transformation (Tabachnik & Fidell, 2013). In case no transformation is useful, we will dichotomize the predictor. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we will report on this. 
•	Residuals will be examined for each model:
o	Deviance residuals. We will examine deviance residuals to detect cases that are not predicted well by the model. We will evaluate whether the proportion of residuals > 3 is approximately 0%, the proportion of residuals > 2.5 is approximately 1%, and the proportion of residuals > 2 is approximately 5%. In case of concern, we will refit the model excluding cases with a deviance residual > 3. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we will report on this.  
o	Schoenfeld residuals. We will plot schoenfeld residuals against ranked event times, and we will test the correlation between schoenfeld residuals and ranked event times, to test the proportionality assumption. A significant correlation indicates violation of the assumption. If the assumption is violated, we will follow recommendations by Singer and Willet (2003), and refit and examine a model including an interaction with time as a predictor, to represent the time varying effect.
o	Score residuals. We will plot score residuals against ranked event times to detect influential and high leverage cases. In case high-influential cases are concentrated at specific event times, we will refit the model excluding observations with extreme score residuals (as the absolute value of score residuals is not meaningful, we will choose the cut-off for extreme values based on visual inspection of the graph). When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we will report on this.

Missing data handling
Pairwise deletion

dependent.value:
Dependent variables and measurement
•	The hazard to stand up when sitting, i.e., the probability of standing up per minute of sitting (precision in seconds)
•	The hazard to sit down when standing, i.e., the probability of sitting down per minute of standing (precision in seconds)

Sitting behaviour is defined as “any waking behaviour characterized by an energy expenditure ≤ 1.5 metabolic equivalents (METs), while in a sitting, reclining or lying posture”. In this study, we distinguish between sitting behaviour and activity, referring to all non-sitting behaviour. Sitting behaviour and activity were assessed using an activPAL3 micro (PAL Technologies Ltd, Glasgow, UK), a device that is worn on the thigh that directly assesses posture using triaxial accelerometry. ActivPALs are known to have a good reliability and validity to measure sitting and activity behaviour (Edwardson et al., 2017) for more information on the activPAL). Placement was standardised to the anterior midline of the upper right thigh, with monitors inserted into a flexible waterproof sleeve and attached using a breathable, hypoallergenic dressing. Participants were asked to wear the monitor 24 hours over an 8-day period and not to remove the monitor. The activPAL measures sitting behaviour and activity with seconds precision, and provides timestamped activity code (sitting/lying down; standing; or stepping) for each transition between postures and each step. For this study, standing and stepping are taken together as active, so the data contains a new row for each sit-active and active-sit transition. 
-	Event times in minutes (precision in seconds) are calculated by subtracting the time of the previous event from the time of the current event, e.g., the time of the previous stand up events is subtracted from the current sit-down event.

Grouping variables
•	CV patients vs. healthy controls (group)
•	Measurement moment regarding cardiac rehabilitation (cr_time): Pre- vs. post- vs. follow-up

Predictor variables and measurement:
- Time of the day (within-participants); In hours since midnight (precision in seconds); Inferred from the time registration in the activPAL data
- Activity in last 5 hours (within-participants); In minutes (precision in seconds); Sum of all active (non-sedentary) time in the 5 hours prior to the current event
- Age (between-participants); In years; Self-report
- Sex (between-participants); Male vs. female; Self-report
- BMI (between-participants); Weight(kg) / Height(m)^2; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Average sitting level (between-participants); Average total sitting time per day in hours (precision in seconds); Calculated from activPAL data

- Comorbid dyslipidaemia (between-participants); Yes vs. No; Retrieved from electronic patient files

hypothesis.value:
The overall aim of the current research is to extend findings from the original study on sitting behaviour amongst CV patients, by using a dynamic approach to investigate patterns of sitting behaviour amongst CV patients and healthy controls (as opposed to average total sitting behaviour on a person or day level).

The study has four aims: 
1.	Investigate differences in baseline (i.e., pre cardiac rehabilitation) sitting patterns between CV patients and healthy controls
2.	Investigate changes in sitting patterns of CV patients from before to after cardiac rehabilitation
3.	Explore the temporal dynamics of sitting behaviour in CV patients compared to healthy controls
4.	Explore individual characteristics and patient characteristics as predictors of sitting patterns of CV patients

Sitting behaviour is conceptualized as a dynamic chain of individual sit-to-stand and stand-to-sit transitions. We use multilevel time-to-event analysis to examine whether the hazard (i.e., the conditional--given that the event has not happened yet--probability that an event occurs per unit of time) to sit down when standing and/or the hazard to stand up when sitting differs in relation to our hypothesized predictors. 

Research questions/hypotheses:

1.	Investigate differences in baseline sitting patterns between CV patients and healthy controls
H1) At baseline, the hazard of standing up when sitting is lower in CV patients compared to healthy controls
H2) At baseline, the hazard of sitting down when standing is higher in CV patients compared to healthy controls.

2.	Investigate changes in sitting patterns of CV patients from before to after cardiac rehabilitation
H3) The hazard of standing up when sitting in CV patients increases from before (pre-) cardiac rehabilitation, to directly after (post-), to two months after (follow-up).
H4) The hazard of sitting down when standing in CV patients decreases from before (pre-) cardiac rehabilitation, to directly after (post-), to two months after (follow-up).

3.	Explore the temporal dynamics of sitting behaviour in CV patients compared to healthy controls
How are the following predictors related to the hazard of standing up when sitting and the hazard of sitting down when standing in CV patients compared to healthy controls?
-	Time of the day (within-participants)
-	Activity in last 5 hours (within-participants)

4.	Explore individual characteristics and patient characteristics as predictors of sitting patterns of CV patients
How are the following predictors related to the hazard of standing up when sitting and to the hazard of sitting down when standing in CV patients, before, directly after, and two months after cardiac rehabilitation?
-	Age (between-participants)
-	Sex (between-participants)
-	BMI (between-participants)
-	Average sitting level (between-participants)
-	Average physical activity level (between-participants)
-	Type of CVD (between-participants)
-	Polypharmacy (between participants)
-	Treatment (between-participants)
-	Comorbid diabetes (between-participants)
-	Comorbid dyslipidaemia (between-participants)
-	Comorbid rheumatoid arthritis or arthrosis (between-participants)
-	Alcohol consumption (between-participants)
-	Smoking status (between-participants)

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: The Temporal Dynamics of Sitting Behaviour in Cardiovascular Disease Patients and the impact of Cardiac Rehabilitation
registration_responses.other:
Existing data:
This study uses existing data collected by the exercise physiology research group at the Radboud University Medical Centre. The original study collected data on sitting behaviour and physical activity in a group of cardiovascular disease (CVD) patients who engaged in cardiac rehabilitation, and a group of healthy, age-matched controls, to (a) compare sitting behaviour characteristics between the two groups and (b) determine the impact of cardiac rehabilitation on sitting behaviour characteristics. 

Secondary analyses per aim:

Aim 2: Investigate changes in sitting patterns of CV patients from before to after cardiac rehabilitation
As a secondary analysis, we additionally compare sitting patterns at post- and follow-up- measurements in CV patients with baseline sitting patterns of healthy controls. 

S1a: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “post”))

S1b: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “follow-up”))

S2a: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “post”))

S2b: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “follow-up”))


 
Aim 3: Explore the temporal dynamics of sitting behaviour in CV patients compared to healthy controls
As a secondary analysis, we additionally compare sitting patterns at post- and follow-up- measurements in CV patients with baseline sitting patterns of healthy controls. 

S3a1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “post”))

S3a2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “post”))

S3b1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “follow-up”))

S3b2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “follow-up”))


S4a1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “post”))

S4a2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “post”))

S4b1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “follow-up”))

S4b2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “follow-up”))

Convergence / singularity issues
When running the shared frailty cox regression model gives convergence or singularity problems, we will walk through the following steps until the problem will be solved:
1.	Rerun the model while disabling the ‘sparse’ method for estimating the correlation matrix. 
2.	Rerun the model with standardized predictors
3.	Simplify the model following recommendations by Barr, Levy, Scheepers, and Tily (2013) 

References
Barr, D. J., Levy, R., Scheepers, C., & Tily, H. J. (2013). Random effects structure for confirmatory hypothesis testing: Keep it maximal. Journal of Memory and Language, 68(3). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jml.2012.11.001
Edwardson, C. L., Winkler, E. A. H., Bodicoat, D. H., Yates, T., Davies, M. J., Dunstan, D. W., & Healy, G. N. (2017). Considerations when using the activPAL monitor in field-based research with adult populations. Journal of Sport and Health Science, 6(2), 162–178. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jshs.2016.02.002
Singer, J. D., & Willet, J. B. (2003). Applied longitudinal data analysis. Oxford University Press.
Therneau, T. M. (2015). A package for survival analysis in S (Version 2.38). http://CRAN.R-project.org/package=survival
Winkler, E., Bodicoat, D., Healy, G., Bakrania, K., Yates, T., Owen, N., Dunstan, D., & Edwardson, C. (2016). Identifying adults’ valid waking wear time by automated estimation in activPAL data collected with a 24 h wear protocol. Physiological Measurement, 37, 1653–1668. https://doi.org/10.1088/0967-3334/37/10/1653
registration_responses.sample:
The study will use existing data. Therefore, sample sizes will be predetermined, namely:
CVD patients: n = 131
Healthy controls: n = 116
registration_responses.analyses:
We will perform all analyses in R / R studio, using the survival package (Therneau, 2015). We will split the complete data into two dataset: 
•	data_sit.to.stand = will only include event times (rows) for sit-to-stand events
•	data_stand.to.sit = will only include events times (rows) for stand-to-sit events
To test our hypotheses and explore our research questions, we will fit several shared frailty cox models using the coxph function, with the predictor(s) of interest, and a frailty term for participant, as predictors of the hazard to stand up when sitting or the hazard to sit down when standing. We will use the ‘efron’ method for handling ties. Unless otherwise specified, for each model, we will determine statistical significance of the fixed effects and/or interaction effects. When statistically significant, we will interpret the hazard ratio (HR; antilog of the raw coefficient) of the fixed predictors or interactions. In addition, we will visually examine plotted survival function separated for relevant levels of the predictor variables. 

1.	Investigate differences in baseline sitting patterns between CV patients and healthy controls
To test H1 and H2, we will use the pre-cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients, and the data of the healthy controls. We will fit two separate shared frailty cox models with group (1 = CV; 0 = control) as predictor. 

H1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “pre”))

H2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “pre”))

2.	Investigate changes in sitting patterns of CV patients from before to after cardiac rehabilitation
To test H3 and H4, we will use the pre-, post-, and follow-up cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients. We will fit two separate shared frailty cox models with measurement moment (pre, post, follow-up; cr_time) as predictor. We will use treatment contrasts for measurement moment, with the pre-measure as the reference category. 
	
H3: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, group = “cv”))

H4: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, group = “cv”))

3.	Explore the temporal dynamics of sitting behaviour in CV patients compared to healthy controls
For Aim 3, we will use the pre-cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients, and the data of the healthy controls. For each predictor, i.e., time of the day and activity in last 5 hours, we will fit four separate shared frailty cox models: two for each dependent variable. Per predictor and dependent variable, Model 1 includes the respective predictor and group (1 = CV; 0 = control) as predictors. In Model 2, the interaction between the respective predictor and group is added. 

Sit-to-stand:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “pre”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, cr_time == “pre”))

Stand-to-sit:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “pre”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + group + predictorxgroup + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, cr_time == “pre”))

4.	Explore individual characteristics and patient characteristics as predictors of sitting patterns of CV patients
For aim 4, we will use the pre-, post-, and follow-up cardiac rehabilitation data of the CV patients. For each predictor listed in Questions 3 and 4, we will fit four separate shared frailty cox models: two for each dependent variable. Per predictor and dependent variable, Model 1 includes the respective predictor and measurement moment (pre, post, follow-up; cr-time) as predictors. In Model 2, the interaction between the respective predictor and measurement moment is added. We will use treatment contrasts for measurement moment variable, with the pre-measure as the reference category. We will summarise HRs and confidence intervals for each predictor and each interaction with measurement moment in a dot-whisker diagram. When statistically significant, we will interpret the Predictor x Measurement moment interaction by visual inspection of graphs. 

Sit-to-stand:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, group == “cv”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + predictorxcr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_sit.to.stand, group == “cv”))

Stand-to-sit:
Model 1: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, group == “cv”))

Model 2: coxph(Surv(event.time.m, event) ~ predictor + cr_time + predictorxcr_time + frailty(ptcpID), data = subset(data_stand.to.sit, group == “cv”))
registration_responses.outliers:
Exclusion criteria
•	Sleep. ActivPAL data during sleep will be identified using self-reported sleep/wake-time diaries from participants. In the original study, an algorithm was used to match self-reported sleep/wake-times to activPAL data. In case the self-reported sleep/wake-times and the activPAL data did not match (i.e., no sedentary episode of long duration starting within the 40 minute time-window around self-reported bedtimes, or ending within the 40 minute timewindow around the self-reported waketimes) these self-reported sleep/wake-times were manually adjusted to plausible bed- or waketimes, based on visual inspection of the activPAL data, as well as consultancy with participants on regular bed and waketimes. These adjusted sleep/wake-time diaries are used for the current study. First, we increase participants self-reported bedtimes and decrease participants self-reported waketimes with 20 minutes. Next, all sedentary and active episodes of a day, that start after the respective adjusted bedtime for that day, and start before the respective adjusted wake time of the next day, are excluded. In addition, all sedentary episodes of a day that end after the adjusted bedtime for that day, and start before the adjusted waketime of the next day, are excluded. 
•	Valid wear-day. We exclude all data on days that are considered invalid wear days (i.e., day on which the participant did not wear the activPAL according to the instructions). A day is considered invalid if at least one of the following criteria is met:
o	One activity takes up more than 95% of totale time awake
o	<500 steps counted
o	<10 hours awake

Assumptions
We will test the assumptions of multilevel time-to-event analysis as follows:
•	Distribution of predictors. We will visually explore histograms to examine the distribution of predictors. In case of serious concerns we will refit the model with a transformation of the predictor variable. We will use a transformation on the predictor that sufficiently creates a normal distribution, starting with square root transformation, followed by log transformation, followed by inverse transformation (Tabachnik & Fidell, 2013). In case no transformation is useful, we will dichotomize the predictor. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we will report on this. 
•	Residuals will be examined for each model:
o	Deviance residuals. We will examine deviance residuals to detect cases that are not predicted well by the model. We will evaluate whether the proportion of residuals > 3 is approximately 0%, the proportion of residuals > 2.5 is approximately 1%, and the proportion of residuals > 2 is approximately 5%. In case of concern, we will refit the model excluding cases with a deviance residual > 3. When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we will report on this.  
o	Schoenfeld residuals. We will plot schoenfeld residuals against ranked event times, and we will test the correlation between schoenfeld residuals and ranked event times, to test the proportionality assumption. A significant correlation indicates violation of the assumption. If the assumption is violated, we will follow recommendations by Singer and Willet (2003), and refit and examine a model including an interaction with time as a predictor, to represent the time varying effect.
o	Score residuals. We will plot score residuals against ranked event times to detect influential and high leverage cases. In case high-influential cases are concentrated at specific event times, we will refit the model excluding observations with extreme score residuals (as the absolute value of score residuals is not meaningful, we will choose the cut-off for extreme values based on visual inspection of the graph). When refitting the model changes the interpretation of the results, we will report on this.

Missing data handling
Pairwise deletion
registration_responses.dependent:
Dependent variables and measurement
•	The hazard to stand up when sitting, i.e., the probability of standing up per minute of sitting (precision in seconds)
•	The hazard to sit down when standing, i.e., the probability of sitting down per minute of standing (precision in seconds)

Sitting behaviour is defined as “any waking behaviour characterized by an energy expenditure ≤ 1.5 metabolic equivalents (METs), while in a sitting, reclining or lying posture”. In this study, we distinguish between sitting behaviour and activity, referring to all non-sitting behaviour. Sitting behaviour and activity were assessed using an activPAL3 micro (PAL Technologies Ltd, Glasgow, UK), a device that is worn on the thigh that directly assesses posture using triaxial accelerometry. ActivPALs are known to have a good reliability and validity to measure sitting and activity behaviour (Edwardson et al., 2017) for more information on the activPAL). Placement was standardised to the anterior midline of the upper right thigh, with monitors inserted into a flexible waterproof sleeve and attached using a breathable, hypoallergenic dressing. Participants were asked to wear the monitor 24 hours over an 8-day period and not to remove the monitor. The activPAL measures sitting behaviour and activity with seconds precision, and provides timestamped activity code (sitting/lying down; standing; or stepping) for each transition between postures and each step. For this study, standing and stepping are taken together as active, so the data contains a new row for each sit-active and active-sit transition. 
-	Event times in minutes (precision in seconds) are calculated by subtracting the time of the previous event from the time of the current event, e.g., the time of the previous stand up events is subtracted from the current sit-down event.

Grouping variables
•	CV patients vs. healthy controls (group)
•	Measurement moment regarding cardiac rehabilitation (cr_time): Pre- vs. post- vs. follow-up

Predictor variables and measurement:
- Time of the day (within-participants); In hours since midnight (precision in seconds); Inferred from the time registration in the activPAL data
- Activity in last 5 hours (within-participants); In minutes (precision in seconds); Sum of all active (non-sedentary) time in the 5 hours prior to the current event
- Age (between-participants); In years; Self-report
- Sex (between-participants); Male vs. female; Self-report
- BMI (between-participants); Weight(kg) / Height(m)^2; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Average sitting level (between-participants); Average total sitting time per day in hours (precision in seconds); Calculated from activPAL data
- Average MVPA level (between-participants); Average total MVPA per day in minutes (precision in seconds); Calculated as the sum of all stepping time with a MET value ≥ 3
- Type of CVD (between-participants); Acute coronary syndrome (ACS; Acute coronary syndrome; Angina Pectoris) vs. Other (Congenital heart disease; Heart failure; Heart rhythm disorder; Heart valve disease; Other CVD); Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Polypharmacy (between-participants); Yes (> 5 medications) vs. No; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Treatment (between-participants); Voronary Artery Bypass Crafting (CABG) vs. Other (Electro cardioversion / ablation / mini-maze procedure; Heart valve replacement; Pacemaker or ICD implementation; PCI; Medication only); Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Comorbid diabetes (between-participants); Yes vs. No; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Comorbid dyslipidaemia (between-participants); Yes vs. No; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Comorbid rheumatoid arthritis or arthrosis (between-participants); Yes vs. No; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Alcohol consumption (between-participants); High vs. Low; Retrieved from electronic patient files
- Smoking status (between-participants); Currently smoking vs. Not currently smoking; Retrieved from electronic patient files

attributes.title: A systematic appraisal of gene-environment interactions in risk of multiple sclerosis: A field synopsis

q1.value: A systematic appraisal of gene-environment interactions in multiple sclerosis: A field synopsis

q2.value: Lazaros Belbasis, Vanesa Bellou, Evropi Theodoratou, Evangelos Evangelou

q3.value: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic neurological disorder and its development involves both genetic and environmental factors. Epidemiological studies have mainly focused on separately studying the contribution of gene-disease and environment-disease associations with risk of MS. A recently published narrative review presented several studies that examined the contribution of gene-environment interactions to the risk of MS. However, a systematic assessment of the epidemiological credibility of the current evidence on gene-environment interactions in MS has not been attempted yet. We aim to systematically appraise the epidemiological studies examining the effect of gene-environment interactions on MS risk through a field synopsis.

q4.value: Several statistically significant gene-environment interactions have been claimed in published studies for MS risk. However, the epidemiological credibility of these interactions has not been systematically assessed. We will apply the Venice criteria to examine the epidemiological credibility of the effect of gene-environment interactions on MS risk.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The present study is a field synopsis, which is a snapshot of the current state of knowledge on associations for risk factors in a particular research field, as defined by a disease or trait, and provides a summary of the cumulative evidence on the etiology of complex diseases and normal traits.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: We will systematically search PubMed to identify epidemiological studies that examined gene-environment interactions and risk for MS. We will consider eligible any observational study (i.e., cohort study, case-control study, or cross-sectional study) that examined the effect of an interaction of a genetic factor with an environmental factor on MS risk.

q13.value: The initial literature search resulted in about 1200 that will be screened by title, abstract and full text. The articles that fulfill our eligibility criteria will be included in our field synopsis.

question.value: From each eligible article, we will extract population characteristics, sample size, study design, the environmental risk factor of interest and the genetic risk factor of interest, the effect size metric and the interaction effect estimate along with its 95% confidence interval.
We will also take notice of the statistical method used to examine the gene-environment interaction. We will examine whether measures of additive or multiplicative interaction were reported.

We will apply the random-effects model to perform a meta-analysis for gene-environment interaction effects that were examined in at least 2 independent populations. We will apply the DerSimonian and Laird method to estimate the tau-square statistic. We will assess and quantify the presence of between-study heterogeneity by calculating the I-square statistic. Also, for interactions examined in at least 3 independent populations, we will estimate the 95% prediction interval, and we will assess the presence of small-study effects by performing the Egger's regression test.

q21.value: To systematically assess the gene-environment interactions, we will adopt a previously proposed approach which is considered an extension of the widely used Venice criteria. Venice criteria constitute a set of methodological criteria to assess the epidemiological credibility of gene-disease associations. This assessment is based on sample size, replication of findings, and protection from bias. The framework for the assessment of gene-environment interactions consists of four steps: (1) assessment of the strength of the evidence for main effects of the environmental exposure and the genetic variant on the outcome of interest, 2) establishment of an a prior score category and decision on the pattern of interaction to be expected, 3) assessment of the strength of the evidence for interaction between the environmental exposure and the genetic variant, and 4) examination of the overall plausibility of the interaction by combining the prior score and the strength of the evidence and interpretation of the findings.

We will consider eligible any observational study (i.e., cohort study, case-control study, or cross-sectional study) that examined the effect of an interaction of a genetic factor with an environmental factor on MS risk.
registration_responses.q17.question: From each eligible article, we will extract population characteristics, sample size, study design, the environmental risk factor of interest and the genetic risk factor of interest, the effect size metric and the interaction effect estimate along with its 95% confidence interval.
registration_responses.q18.question: We will also take notice of the statistical method used to examine the gene-environment interaction. We will examine whether measures of additive or multiplicative interaction were reported.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will apply the random-effects model to perform a meta-analysis for gene-environment interaction effects that were examined in at least 2 independent populations. We will apply the DerSimonian and Laird method to estimate the tau-square statistic. We will assess and quantify the presence of between-study heterogeneity by calculating the I-square statistic. Also, for interactions examined in at least 3 independent populations, we will estimate the 95% prediction interval, and we will assess the presence of small-study effects by performing the Egger's regression test.

attributes.title: A Quasi-Experimental Study on the Effectiveness of a Play Intervention on Children’s Difficult Behaviors, Internet Dependency and Playing Time

q1.value: A Quasi-Experimental Study on the Effectiveness of a Play Intervention on Children’s Difficult Behaviors and Playing Time

q2.value: Patrick WB Tsui, Christian S. Chan, Liu So Yu Christine

q3.value:
Play is important for the physical, social and psychological development of children (Ginsburg, 2007) but the amount of time allocated on play has been on the decline in modern culture (Ginsberg, 2007; Gray 2011).

The current research aims to examine the effectiveness of a play intervention on improving children’s difficult behaviours and reducing children’s internet dependency. It also aims to examine its associated changes to interactive time and parent-child relationship. 

Both the experimental and wait list control groups will be sent a series of videos on the importance of play. The experimental group will be introduced to a smartphone application known as Plaily, which contains a searchable database of games where the parent and the child can play interactively. 

The waitlist control group will have delayed access to Plaily

In the current study, we aim to investigate: 
The effects of the play intervention on difficult behaviours in children
The effects of the play intervention on internet dependency behaviours in children.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Children in the experimental group will display significantly fewer difficult behaviours than those in the waitlist control condition.

Hypothesis 2:  Children in the experimental group will display significantly less internet dependency behaviours  than those in the waitlist control condition

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a 2 (condition) X 2 (time) mixed design study. The within-subjects independent variable is time (before vs. after the play intervention). The between-subjects independent variable is condition (experimental vs. waitlist-control group).

Participating non-governmental organizations, kindergartens and primary schools in Hong Kong will be randomly assigned to either experimental or waitlist control group.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Recruitment
Participants will be recruited  (1) through kindergartens and primary schools in Hong Kong, (2)  through  Non-profit organizations. (3)  in the community using email and social media


Eligibility Criteria
Inclusion criteria are parents who: (1) have a child aged between 4-10, (2) are able to read Chinese and (3) are users of iPhone or iPad, (the Plaily app is only available on the Apple App Store). 

Procedure
First, participants from both experimental and waitlist control groups will complete an online pre-intervention questionnaire.

Next, participants from both experimental and waitlist control groups will be given videos on  ‘The Importance of Play’ conducted in Chinese. Participants in the experimental group will be introduced to the Plaily app in one of the videos and they will be encouraged to use the Plaily app in the following three weeks. 


Three weeks after intervention videos are sent to participants, participants from both experimental and waitlist control groups will complete an online post-intervention questionnaire. Participants in the waitlist control group will only be introduced to the Plaily app after they have completed the online post-intervention questionnaire. Participants from the experimental group will also be invited to complete a Plaily user evaluation form; while those from the waitlist control group will complete a cross-condition contamination check to ensure that they have not used the Plaily app during the study period.


During the three weeks after the videos are sent, two short questions about play habits will be sent to the parent’s mobile phones to collect data about their play habits. 


Upon completion of the study, participants from both groups will be invited to enter into a lucky draw with a chance to win 1 adult and 1 child ticket to the Ocean Park Hong Kong. The winner will be notified by email.

Timeline
- Participant recruitment: March-May 2020
- Pre-intervention questionnaire: March-June 2020
- Diary-style sampling survey and post-intervention questionnaire: March-June 2020

q13.value:
Our target sample size is 52 parents (26 per condition). 

We will attempt to recruit 75 participants (52 per condition, assuming a dropout rate of 30% over the two timepoints.)

q14.value:
The software program G*Power 3.1 was used to conduct a power analysis. 
Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a small effect size of .2 at standard .05 alpha error probability. 

Statistical test used is F test for ANOVA: Repeated measures, within-between interaction. Number of groups is two, and the number of measurements is two. Correlations among measures are assumed to be .5.

question.value:
All measures will be displayed in Chinese.

1. Children’s Difficult Behaviors
The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (Goodman, 1997) will be used in the online pre-intervention and post-intervention questionnaires to measure participants’ rating of their child’s emotional symptoms and conduct problems. Each item is rated on a 3-point Likert scale, ranging from “Not True” to “Certainly True”. The total difficulties score, subscale scores of  emotional symptoms and conduct problem score will be computed. 

2. Children’s Internet Dependency Behaviors
The 15-items Parent-Child Internet Addiction Test (PCIAT) will be used in the online pre-intervention and post-intervention questionnaires to measure participants’ rating of their child’s Internet dependency behaviors. Each item is rated on a 4-point Likert scale, ranging from “Not applicable” to “Always”. A mean score will be computed.

Hypothesis 1:
A 2x2 mixed ANOVA will be used to test if total difficulties score, conduct problems score and emotional symptom score  (i.e. difference between pre- and post-intervention) is significantly lower in the experimental group than the waitlist control group post intervention. Demographic variables that differed across groups will be included as covariates. As such, ANCOVA will be used for the analysis.

 Hypothesis 2: 
A 2x2 mixed ANOVA will be used to test if the decrease  in      internet dependency (i.e. difference between pre- and post-intervention) is significantly higher in the experimental group than the waitlist control group post intervention. Demographic variables that differed across groups will be included as covariates. As such, ANCOVA will be used for the analysis.

q22.value: Participants in the waitlist control group who have downloaded or used or viewed the Plaily app during the study period will be withdrawn. Data of outliers and participants who did not complete the post-workshop survey are to be retained and analysed.

q24.value:
Exploratory Analysis 1: Increase in play time mediates the relationship between group condition and children’s difficult behaviours 

We expect that the increase in interactive play time may be contributing to the change in child’s behavior. Therefore, we will also look into the relationship between the play intervention, interactive play time and difficult behaviors in children. Change in interactive play time could be the mediating factor between the use of Plaily app and the change in children’s behavior. 



     
Exploratory Analysis 2: 

We expect that the increase in interactive play time may be contributing to the change in child’s internet dependency behavior. Therefore, we will also look into the relationship between the play intervention, interactive play time and internet dependency behavior in children. Change in interactive play time could be the mediating factor between the use of Plaily app and the change in children’s behavior. 


Exploratory analysis 3: The use of the Plaily app significantly increases parent-child interactive play time in the experimental group.

Participants from both experimental and waitlist control groups will also complete a diary style sampling survey daily via their whatsapp/email/apps on their mobile phones over the three weeks after the workshop. Items will be used in experience sampling to collect information regarding participants’ daily usage of the plaily app and their time spent on interactive play with their children. Multi-level modelling will be used to test if using the Plaily app will significantly increase parent-child interactive play time. 

Exploratory Analysis 5: We expect to see a correlation between the play intervention,  interactive play time and parent-child relationship

Exploratory Analysis 6:
We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to existing play habits in families. Therefore we will look for relationships between demographic information of parents (e.g. age, occupation and socio-economic status) with parent-child relationship and play time.

q25.value:
References: 
Driscoll, K., & Pianta, R. C. (2011). Mothers' and Fathers' Perceptions of Conflict and Closeness in Parent-Child Relationships during Early Childhood. Journal of Early Childhood & Infant Psychology(7).

Ginsburg, K. R. (2007). The importance of play in promoting healthy child development and maintaining strong parent-child bonds. Pediatrics, 119(1), 182-191.

Goodman, R. (1997). The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire: a research note. Journal of child psychology and psychiatry, 38(5), 581-586.

McSherry, D., Fargas Malet, M., & Weatherall, K. (2019). The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ): A proxy measure of parenting stress. The British Journal of Social Work, 49(1), 96-115.

Young, K. S. (1999). Parent-child internet addiction test. Retrieved June, 18, 2004.

attributes.title: Meta-analysis and meta-regression analysis of adverse events in placebo randomized controlled trials of chloroquine phosphate against viral infection

q1.value: Meta-analysis and meta-regression analysis of adverse events in placebo randomized controlled trials of chloroquine phosphate against viral infection

q4.value: We will perform a systematic review and meta-analysis of the adverse events of chloroquine phosphate as the antiviral therapy.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: In this study, we will present a comprehensive systematic review of all placebo-controlled randomized clinical trials (RCTs) containing chloroquine phosphate for the treatment of viral infection since its introduction in 1938 till March 2020, and make a meta-analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will perform a comprehensive literature search of articles through the following databases without date limitation: PubMed, EMBASE, The Cochrane Library, Web of Science, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Data, and CQVIP. 
The PICOS inclusion criteria for selecting the studies for this meta-analysis are as follows: (1) chloroquine used for the treatment of patients with viral infection; (2) chloroquine versus placebo; (3) The primary outcome was the adverse events associated with chloroquine treatment; (4) the study design was restricted to randomized controlled trials. The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) patients < 18 years old and studies involving animals; (2) studies on non-viral diseases; (3) the adverse events were not evaluated; (4) meeting abstracts, letters to the editor, case reports and reviews.

meta-analysis, Trial sequential analysis , Meta-regression analysis
